http://www.lsoft.com/images/listserv-community.gif http://www.lsoft.com/images/listserv_small.gif DATA-PROTECTION List DATA-PROTECTION List Archives https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk/cgi-bin/webadmin?RSS&L=data-protection&v=ATOM1.0
This is an Atom formatted XML site feed. It is intended to be viewed in a Newsreader. Alternatively you can view the HTML archives at https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk/cgi-bin/webadmin?A0=data-protection.
LISTSERV Web Interface 2.4.1 2015-03-12T16:17:14Z IRMS Chair 2015-03-12T16:07:09+00:00 2015-03-12T16:07:09+00:00 Re: Early retirement https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;d7896a1d.1503 Nick<br><br>On behalf of all your many colleagues and friends on both the RM and DP<br>lists and also within the IRMS, may I be one of the first of many to wish<br>you a fabulous retirement.<br><br>With warmest regards<br><br>Meic<br>Meic Pierce Owen AMIRMS<br>IRMS Chair<br><br>On 12 March 2015 at 14:55, Kingsley, Nick <<br>Nick.Kingsley@nationalarchives.gsi.gov.uk> wrote:<br><br>> Dear Colleagues and Friends,<br>><br>><br>><br>> I thought you might like to know that I announced a couple of days ago<br>> that I will be taking slightly early retirement from The National Archives<br>> with effect from 8th [...] Ibrahim Hasan 2015-03-12T11:39:26+00:00 2015-03-12T11:39:26+00:00 Adv - Revised RIPA Policy and Procedures Toolkit (2015) https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;3e67c31e.1503 Colleagues<br><br>We have just produced an updated version of our RIPA Policy and Procedures Toolkit. This takes account of the new RIPA codes of practice which came into force in December 2014.<br><br>It includes an updated version of our previous RIPA Forms Guidance document, which was bought by over one hundred different organisations. There are also detailed guidance notes on deciding when surveillance is caught by RIPA, how to authorise it and what to do about surveillance which is not regulated by RIPA. The toolkit is written in straightforward language (avoiding legal jargon) and includes flowcharts to assist understanding. [...] Kate Glanville 2015-03-11T09:34:58+00:00 2015-03-11T09:34:58+00:00 Re: Custodial sentences and DP https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;f0e6cc02.1503 Hi all<br><br>Thanks very much for your help. This is really useful.<br><br>With kind regards<br><br>Kate<br>DPO Officer<br>DCH Baines, Jonathan 2015-03-10T10:57:44+00:00 2015-03-10T10:57:44+00:00 Re: Custodial sentences and DP https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;f1e21af9.1503 This would have been a section 55 DPA creates an offence of, in terms, unlawfully acquiring personal data. Currently it is triable either in the Magistrates' Court, in which case the maximum fine is \ufffd\ufffd5000 or in the County Court, in which case the maximum fine is unlimited.<br><br>Section 77 of the Criminal Justice and Investigations Act give the Secretary of State the power effectively to amend - *if she/he chooses to do so* - the DPA so that a custodial sentence would be one of the sentencing options open to the court. [...] Chris Pounder 2015-03-10T10:50:35-00:00 2015-03-10T10:50:35-00:00 Re: Custodial sentences and DP https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;5eab3823.1503 S.55 non custodial; it is caught up with Leveson. The prospect of locking up Journalists does not appeal<br><br>See http://amberhawk.typepad.com/amberhawk/2013/08/section-55-custodial-offence-left-waiting-for-leveson-and-party-politics.html<br><br>Blog starts: The Government has decided not to commence the custodial element of the Section 55 offence of the Data Protection Act until the Leveson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds recommendations in relation to the press regulation are done and dusted. Indeed, I now suspect that the Government does not want to commence a custodial S.55 offence at all. [...] Trish-louise Bailey 2015-03-10T10:48:43+00:00 2015-03-10T10:48:43+00:00 Re: Custodial sentences and DP https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;b71d0b37.1503 Hi all<br><br>I seem to recall case law where a nurse used her access to obtain ex boyfriend medical records and published pieces of info to "cause him distress". Nurse was prosecuted and breach of DPA was cited by judge and ex boyfriend awarded \ufffd\ufffd15k (I think) damages. It was the first of its kind where direct reference to DPA was cited. [...] Baines, Jonathan 2015-03-10T10:38:10+00:00 2015-03-10T10:38:10+00:00 Re: Custodial sentences and DP https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;701d0779.1503 "I phoned the DP Helpline at the ICO but they were not aware of this provision. However, they obviously pointed out that it is not legislation that they cover anyway"<br><br>Extraordinary.<br><br>Jon Baines,<br>Chairman<br>www.nadpo.org.uk<br><br>-----Original Message-----<br>From: This list is for those interested in Data Protection issues [mailto:data-protection@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] On Behalf Of Andrew Goodfellow-Swaap<br>Sent: 10 March 2015 10:29<br>To: data-protection@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject: Re: [data-protection] Custodial sentences and DP [...] Andrew Goodfellow-Swaap 2015-03-10T10:28:50+00:00 2015-03-10T10:28:50+00:00 Re: Custodial sentences and DP https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;df95383f.1503 Hi Kate,<br><br>I think your colleague is referring to s.77 and s.144 of the CJ&I 2008.<br><br>S.77 - Power to alter penalty for unlawfully obtaining etc. personal data.<br><br>(1)The Secretary of State may by order provide for a person who is guilty of an offence under section 55 of the Data Protection Act 1998 (c. 29) (unlawful obtaining etc. of personal data) to be liable\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd .<br>(a)on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding the specified period or to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum or to both, .<br>(b)on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a [...] Jane Holden 2015-03-10T10:26:21+00:00 2015-03-10T10:26:21+00:00 Re: Custodial sentences and DP https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;79ee8b86.1503 Hello Kate<br><br>I believe this answers your question http://www.cps.gov.uk/legal/d_to_g/data_protection/<br><br>"Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008<br><br>Section 77 Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008 came into force on Royal Assent on 8 May 2008. Section 77 gives the Secretary of State the power to alter the penalty for an offence of unlawful obtaining etc. of personal data contrary to section 55 of the DPA. The Secretary of State has not increased the penalty for a section 55 DPA offence. Areas will be informed if this power is exercised." [...] Phil Bradshaw 2015-03-10T10:26:07+00:00 2015-03-10T10:26:07+00:00 Re: Custodial sentences and DP https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;c4f28ee5.1503 Indeed there is such a power in s77 of the Act. It has not been exercised nor does there seem to be much inclination to do so at present, so far as I am aware. ICO would be consulted before any implemenation - see s77(4). If it ever were implemented ICO would clearly be involved in any prosecution process, even if the formal responsibility was with the police or CPS. [...] Kate Glanville 2015-03-10T10:12:56+00:00 2015-03-10T10:12:56+00:00 Custodial sentences and DP https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;fb8d1472.1503 Hi there<br><br>I have had a query from one of my colleagues and I wondered if anyone could shed light on it please?<br><br>I am aware that currently there is no custodial sentence in the event of a DPA Section 55 offence. However, my colleague has said that "under the Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008 there is provision for the introduction of new civil penalties for serious breaches of data protection of data protection principles and makes unlawfully obtaining personal data a custodial offence punishable by up to two years in prison". [...] Gudge, Teresa 2015-03-09T11:43:35+00:00 2015-03-09T11:43:35+00:00 Re: Takeovers -v- fair processing notices https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;a460dac3.1503 Thank you all for your advice - I've looked at the ICO guidance and I've read all the other mails with advice - many thanks<br><br>T<br><br>Teresa Gudge<br>Information Security & Data Protection Manager<br>Tel: 07717800989<br>Email : teresa.gudge@english-heritage.org.uk<br><br>-----Original Message-----<br>From: Fitzpatrick, Anthony [mailto:anthony.fitzpatrick@merseytravel.gov.uk]<br>Sent: 09 March 2015 11:32<br>To: Gudge, Teresa; data-protection@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject: RE: Takeovers -v- fair processing notices [...] Fitzpatrick, Anthony 2015-03-09T11:31:59+00:00 2015-03-09T11:31:59+00:00 Re: Takeovers -v- fair processing notices https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;cf740553.1503 The ICO\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Data Sharing Code of Practice touched on the transfer of personal data when there is a merger or a takeover. The relevant information can be found in Section 6. https://ico.org.uk/media/for-organisations/documents/1068/data_sharing_code_of_practice.pdf Tony -----Original Message----- From: This list is for those interested in Data Protection issues [mailto:data-protection@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] On Behalf Of Gudge, Teresa Sent: 09 March 2015 10:34 To: data-protection@JISCMAIL.AC.UK Subject: [data-protection] Takeovers -v- fair processing notices Good Morning fellow Jiscmailers If a company ceases to trade and it holds personal data which has been gathered legitimately how does the organisation taking over the operations of the folding company stand with [...] Tim Turner 2015-03-09T11:12:50+00:00 2015-03-09T11:12:50+00:00 Re: Takeovers -v- fair processing notices https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;e225c0f7.1503 It\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds a wholly different situation to one involving receivers. Receivers have a specific job to do that is largely unrelated to the normal activity of a business, and is about paying debts etc. Teresa\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds scenario is one business using the data for the same processing activities as the one whose data it is buying. [...] Lawrence Serewicz 2015-03-09T11:10:48+00:00 2015-03-09T11:10:48+00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;159d219d.1503 Roland,<br>Thanks for the post. Yes, shotguns are readily available after a waiting period.<br><br>The issue of restricted purchases is something that is now of increased interest in the age of big data.<br><br>I know that some items can only be purchased with the appropriate licence. In other cases, what might have been household items are now either diluted or no longer for sale over the counter. [...] Lawrence Serewicz 2015-03-09T11:04:44+00:00 2015-03-09T11:04:44+00:00 Re: Takeovers -v- fair processing notices https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;11d584f0.1503 Teresa,<br>I am not sure on the exact question. However, it does sound similar to the case in which a firm of receivers takes over a company and has to handle SARs. The principles will be similar in that the company that collected it is not the same as the one who holds it and processes it. [...] Marchini, Renzo 2015-03-09T10:58:49+00:00 2015-03-09T10:58:49+00:00 Re: Takeovers -v- fair processing notices https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;ab2075f8.1503 Hi Teresa<br><br>The answer to many of your questions are in this ICO guidance: https://ico.org.uk/media/for-organisations/documents/2665/buying_and_selling_customer_databases.pdf<br><br>But in brief:<br><br>If a company ceases to trade and it holds personal data which has been gathered legitimately how does the organisation taking over the operations of the folding company stand with regard to contacting individuals ?<br>It is a new data controller and would have to give a notice to the data subjects.<br>Would the new organisation carry on as the old one had and use the data for the purpose it was collected by the old company ?<br>Yes, it could, and [...] Gudge, Teresa 2015-03-09T10:33:40+00:00 2015-03-09T10:33:40+00:00 Takeovers -v- fair processing notices https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;6ae5bb15.1503 Good Morning fellow Jiscmailers<br><br>If a company ceases to trade and it holds personal data which has been gathered legitimately how does the organisation taking over the operations of the folding company stand with regard to contacting individuals ?<br><br>Would the new organisation carry on as the old one had and use the data for the purpose it was collected by the old company ? [...] Roland Perry 2015-03-09T09:58:40+00:00 2015-03-09T09:58:40+00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;2dcf5faf.1503 In message<br><23FA0E072CAB3C44A25061392F1CB54B9F17BB6B@WILYKAT.durham.gov.uk>, at<br>09:19:02 on Mon, 9 Mar 2015, Lawrence Serewicz<br><Lawrence.Serewicz@DURHAM.GOV.UK> writes<br>>On the first point I agree. Phil makes the point well. I use it in<br>>training and it is the point that gets most attention from managers and<br>>employees.<br>>On the second point it is hard to connect to health. Someone may<br>>purchase alcohol\ufffd\ufffd to cook but not to drink. [...] Lawrence Serewicz 2015-03-09T09:19:02+00:00 2015-03-09T09:19:02+00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;d3e819eb.1503 On the first point I agree. Phil makes the point well. I use it in training and it is the point that gets most attention from managers and employees.<br><br>On the second point it is hard to connect to health. Someone may purchase alcohol to cook but not to drink.<br><br>On paracetamol, yes multiple purchases on the same day or over several days cannot be stopped. What it does di, though, is slow down impulse purchases for the purposes of suicide. Usually these occur on impulse but some are planned in advanced. [...] Chris Spray 2015-03-08T22:11:02-00:00 2015-03-08T22:11:02-00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;6050792b.1503 The first quote: "the mere mentioning of the fact that somebody is ill in an employment context are all data concerning the health of individual data subjects" is in conflict with the ICO employment practices code.<br><br>In this the ICO draws a distinction between an absence record stating that someone was off sick without specifying any particular condition (not SPD) and a sickness or injury record containing details of the condition (SPD). [...] Roland Perry 2015-03-08T19:52:34+00:00 2015-03-08T19:52:34+00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;92d330f7.1503 In message <49A8D132-8D2D-4448-9CFB-70CAAA7531D4@grimbaldus.com>, at<br>18:32:19 on Sun, 8 Mar 2015, Michael Bacon - Grimbaldus<br><michael.bacon@GRIMBALDUS.COM> writes<br><br>>The Royal Pharmaceutical Society has a detailed table. The maximum<br>>pack size for non-effervescent tablets and capsules is non-pharmacy<br>>outlets is indeed 16, with a maximum of 100 tablets<br><br><http://www.rpharms.com/legal-classification-of-medicines-<br>db/paracetamol-legal-status-table.asp><br><br>>(there is no limit on effervescent tablets/capsules and powders/granules).<br><br>After surgery, I was once prescribed effervescent tablets in<br>considerable bulk[1], and when querying this with the pharmacist they<br>said it was physically impossible to overdose on them because that much<br>fizz would cause you to throw up the whole lot. [...] Michael Bacon - Grimbaldus 2015-03-08T18:32:19+00:00 2015-03-08T18:32:19+00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;884599d4.1503 I bow to that.<br><br>The Royal Pharmaceutical Society has a detailed table. The maximum pack size for non-effervescent tablets and capsules is non-pharmacy outlets is indeed 16, with a maximum of 100 tablets (there is no limit on effervescent tablets/capsules and powders/granules).<br><br>Anecdote though suggests that many retailers are limiting sales to one pack of 16. This might be assistants not understanding the law (not uncommon), or over-zealous application by local managers anxious not to risk their jobs because of an assistant's error (more common in some retailers). [...] Roland Perry 2015-03-08T15:48:11+00:00 2015-03-08T15:48:11+00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;f33a9195.1503 In message <857B9B42-8188-4EFC-8AE1-F78EBC729630@grimbaldus.com>, at<br>14:22:44 on Sun, 8 Mar 2015, Michael Bacon - Grimbaldus<br><michael.bacon@GRIMBALDUS.COM> writes<br>>Pharmacists can sell 32 tablets, other retailers can only sell 16 at a<br>>time.<br><br>I think that's "pack size" not "single purchase limit".<br><br>>If you pay using a payment card, or with a loyalty card, a large retailer<br>>can/will link the purchases. [...] Michael Bacon - Grimbaldus 2015-03-08T14:22:44+00:00 2015-03-08T14:22:44+00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;7e31d4.1503 Indeed the purchase could be made for a household, but remember 'Big Data'. Large retailers (e.g. Supermarket chains) know increasing amounts about identified customers [note the 'identifED'], including the number of souls in the household - of course, the customer might be buying for friends, or to stock their village store, etc. BTW, most people have little idea how much their friendly supermarket knows about them ... it's a LOT, and growing. [...] Roland Perry 2015-03-08T13:42:26+00:00 2015-03-08T13:42:26+00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;38670c2f.1503 In message <8569528729621133.WA.igwalesgmail.com@www.jiscmail.ac.uk>, at<br>11:45:45 on Sun, 8 Mar 2015, Phil Bradshaw <igwales@GMAIL.COM> writes<br>>They are already (or some of them) aware that some purchases may be 'sensitive' even if not strictly 'sensitive personal data' so that e.g.<br>>there are some purchases, even if regular, which will not generate a related Tesco club card voucher with money off your next purchase. Whether<br>>they would be happy to take the next step and willingly classify it as sensitive PD with all the additional burdens that entails may be rather<br>>different. [...] Roland Perry 2015-03-08T13:33:28+00:00 2015-03-08T13:33:28+00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;1455ccdf.1503 In message <EAC1ACC8-297F-4196-AA94-263E5449FEDC@grimbaldus.com>, at<br>11:26:33 on Sun, 8 Mar 2015, Michael Bacon - Grimbaldus<br><michael.bacon@GRIMBALDUS.COM> writes<br><br>>And the statement that: "health data therefore also include information<br>>about a person's ...\ufffd\ufffdexcessive alcohol consumption, tobacco consumption<br>>or drug use" begs the question whether retailers' customer histories<br>>might be said to contain SPD, if, for example, a customer routinely<br>>purchases booze in excess of the recommended number of units per week, [...] Phil Bradshaw 2015-03-08T11:45:45+00:00 2015-03-08T11:45:45+00:00 Re: A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;77864227.1503 The first of Michael's points I have no problem with, and I have always used this issue in a training context e.g. pointing out that it is a 'breach' to answer the phone with "I'm sorry John is off sick today, Can I help" or to write "sick leave" on the office whiteboard. Not only is this technically correct I have found it helps bring the point home that we always need to keep our mind's in gear on DP even in everyday situations. [...] Michael Bacon - Grimbaldus 2015-03-08T11:26:33+00:00 2015-03-08T11:26:33+00:00 A bit of a Friday question : Art 29 WP letter on health data https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;f2c2887c.1503 The Annex to this recent letter (http://ec.europa.eu/justice/data-protection/article-29/documentation/other-document/files/2015/20150205_letter_art29wp_ec_health_data_after_plenary_annex_en.pdf) makes for interesting and somewhat disturbing reading, especially for the private sector.<br><br>For example, that statement that, "the mere mentioning of the fact that somebody is ill in an employment context are all data concerning the health of individual data subjects" brings email within the context of systems that process SPD, with business-related emails such as: "Fred's off sick, can you cover?" and social ones such as:"Is Freda's cough better?" [...] Phil Bradshaw 2015-03-06T10:56:24+00:00 2015-03-06T10:56:24+00:00 Re: Original docs as proof of ID https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;f59da3e6.1503 On Derek's point "it does not matter if they lived the other side of the world - I don't think it unreasonable to ask they send them by recorded/special delivery - they will rightly expect me to return their documentation and their resulting SAR information in the same manner."<br><br>I would simply add that this should not be a rule. The assessment must be reasonable, on a case by case basis - see e.g. the SAR Code of Practice ("For example, if a request is made by means of an email account through which you have recently corresponded with the [...] Phil Bradshaw 2015-03-06T10:42:31+00:00 2015-03-06T10:42:31+00:00 Re: Changing occupational health providers https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;d08a8e0f.1503 I would always recommend tracking down and considering the National Archives RM guidance on transfer of functions on such matters - although it may have been replaced with this http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/documents/information-management/machinery_of_government.pdf Phil Bradshaw 2015-03-06T10:34:38+00:00 2015-03-06T10:34:38+00:00 Re: Friday comes early ... https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;91353c02.1503 Like Trish-Louise I have not had time to look up the precedent but she is absolutely right. There is clear case law on this. At least one case I recall was where a DC refused to post to a house in mulitiple-occupation and was held to have breached s7 / principle 6. [...] Andrew Goodfellow-Swaap 2015-03-06T09:28:34+00:00 2015-03-06T09:28:34+00:00 Re: Original docs as proof of ID https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;7a47feea.1503 This is exactly why we encourage requesters to send certified copies. The risk of an original going missing just seems too high (in that we've had it occur) even with recorded or special delivery.<br><br>That said, we would (and have) arrange alternative methods of confirmation if the requester was reluctant or unable, to send any ID through the post. For example an email/letter (on headed paper of course) from a verifiable professional e.g. a social worker, GP, solicitor etc. [...] Derek O'Connor 2015-03-06T09:12:01+00:00 2015-03-06T09:12:01+00:00 Re: Original docs as proof of ID https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;ee8f1deb.1503 Definitely - it does not matter if they lived the other side of the world - I don't think it unreasonable to ask they send them by recorded/special delivery - they will rightly expect me to return their documentation and their resulting SAR information in the same manner.<br><br>If a data controller discloses personal information to a 3rd party on the basis that they purported to be the data subject, and the data controller had accepted photocopy confirmation that fact, does anyone believe that that would be robust defence if the ICO investigated? [...] Ibrahim Hasan 2015-03-06T08:33:39+00:00 2015-03-06T08:33:39+00:00 Information Governance Job Vacancy https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;320f0ef5.1503 London Councils is looking for an Information Governance Project Manager to help implement new information management policies:<br><br>http://www.londoncouncils.gov.uk/aboutus/careers/job.htm?pk=170<br><br>The closing date is 16th March 2015.<br><br>Ibrahim Hasan<br><br>Solicitor and Director<br>Act Now Training Limited<br><br>www.actnow.org.uk Roland Perry 2015-03-06T07:48:42+00:00 2015-03-06T07:48:42+00:00 Re: Original docs as proof of ID https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;597de3dc.1503 In message<br><B5BE008CE8159D4B927F5D901E8ADFE5035F0EE5@cm-exmbx01.corp.conwy.gov.uk>,<br>at 14:05:59 on Thu, 5 Mar 2015, Derek O'Connor<br><Derek.Oconnor@CONWY.GOV.UK> writes<br>>I would accept an SAR electronically and respond electronically with the data (by secure means obviously) but would not accept proof of ID<br>>electronically.<br>><br>>I think all those who accept photocopies of ID (either electronically or otherwise) are taking a risk (calculated maybe, but still a risk) -<br>>photocopies could be easily tampered with and if it transpired that you disclosed information to someone not entitled to receive it you will<br>>likely incur the wrath of the ICO.<br>><br>>Original docs can be fraudulent I [...] Trish-louise Bailey 2015-03-06T05:50:29+00:00 2015-03-06T05:50:29+00:00 Re: Friday comes early ... https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=data-protection;fc9f5e0b.1503 Hi Chris<br><br>I can take a look and let the list know, it was a few years ago between a council and a resident who was blind. The council changed its security policy - post 2008 - and started sending letters only.<br><br>The resident used to receive correspondence by email and used browse-aloud type software to verbalise the content. I believe a photocopy is 'reasonable' check unless evidence in a particular case points otherwise. Yes, a person may own or associate with the machine and therefore it is personal data for the purposes of the UK DPA and the EU Article 29 Working Party. However, the wider issue of privacy in the digital age is that we are not certain that the person at the MAC address or IP address is the person listed.
